title: Judgment debtor threatens to file bankruptcy after sheriff serves bank levy.
question: I had the sheriff's department execute a bank levy against the judgment debtor last week for a judgment awarded in small claims court. The judgment debtor is now threatening to file bankruptcy. I'm not sure what this means for me. Here is where the process stands:
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Bankruptcy court,Credit,Debt,Nondischargeable debts,Bankruptcy and debt,Small claims court
answers: If the debtor files bankruptcy, I suggest you consult bankruptcy counsel to determine what, if anything, you can and should do to protect your interests. In that event you should not take any further action to enforce your judgment without consultation and approval of counsel.

A BK means you must stop all collection activity. The debt will be dischargeable unless it is a nondischargeable Debt under 11 USC 523.

You can always check PACER to see if someone has filed. If you are close in proximity to the BK Court you can check the docket to see if the Debtor filed at the Courthouse, you will usually have access to computers so that you may check the docket.
http://www.pacer.gov/

The threat to file BK, and the actual filing, are different things. The BK stay does not go into effect until there is an actual filing. There are complicated forms to complete; that is why a BK debtor should use an attorney. If the debtor does not do the paperwork properly, the BK might get dismissed. Also, the debtor must qualify for BK under the "means test." And, the debtor must consider the effect of filing BK. It will be on his/her credit for 10 years. It will affect all of his/her other financial obligations. All credit card accounts will be closed. All financial assets, and all financial obligations, must be disclosed.

I suggest that you wait to see whether the debtor actual does file. If not, you will have whatever money the Sheriff recovers. If the debtor does file, get a copy of his/her BK petition and related filings. See whether the BK is completed, or whether it is dismissed for failure to file all of the necessary documents. And attend the Meeting of Creditors.

The filing of a bankruptcy will stop all collection efforts until the stay has been lifted by the bankruptcy court. Bankruptcy Judges are notorious for sanctions when debt collectors continue to collect after getting notice of the bankruptcy. A talk with a debt collection attorney could keep you on the straight and narrow.
